articles.headline: Pot Was Flying Off the Shelves in Uruguay. Then U.S. Banks Weighed In.
articles.snippet: Uruguay is the first country in the world to fully legalize recreational marijuana. But its new market may be imperiled by United States laws like the Patriot Act.
articles.abstract: Uruguay is the first country in the world to fully legalize recreational marijuana. But its new market may be imperiled by United States laws like the Patriot Act.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pharmacies selling pot were doing a brisk business.

articles.headline: In Social Media Era, Selfies Are the New Tupperware Party
articles.snippet: The success of Rodan & Fields, maker of Lash Boost, shows that people can be persuaded to buy all kinds of products based on friends’ testimonials.
articles.abstract: The success of Rodan & Fields, maker of Lash Boost, shows that people can be persuaded to buy all kinds of products based on friends’ testimonials.
articles.lead_paragraph: The pitch comes in the form of before and after photos posted to Facebook or Instagram by a woman you know. The focus is on her eyes, specifically her eyelashes, which at first appear ordinary and untouched — a stark contrast from a picture taken weeks later, when they look long and thick. Mascara magnifies the effect in another snapshot.

articles.headline: Wine War in Southern France Has Streets Running Red
articles.snippet: Winemakers in the region say their livelihoods are threatened by unfair competition under European trade rules. Now they’re in revolt.
articles.abstract: Winemakers in the region say their livelihoods are threatened by unfair competition under European trade rules. Now they’re in revolt.
articles.lead_paragraph: BÉZIERS, France — On a late evening in March, a group of winegrowers wearing black balaclavas forced their way into one of France’s largest wine brokerages and ignited three Molotov cocktails. Within minutes, the business, Passerieux Vergnes Diffusion, was in flames.

articles.headline: Trump Pardons Joe Arpaio, Who Became Face of Crackdown on Illegal Immigration
articles.snippet: Mr. Arpaio, the former Arizona sheriff who built a national reputation for his efforts to hunt and detain undocumented immigrants, had been convicted of criminal contempt.
articles.abstract: Mr. Arpaio, the former Arizona sheriff who built a national reputation for his efforts to hunt and detain undocumented immigrants, had been convicted of criminal contempt.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump on Friday pardoned Joe Arpaio, the former Arizona sheriff whose aggressive efforts to hunt down and detain undocumented immigrants made him a national symbol of the divisive politics of immigration and earned him a criminal contempt conviction.
articles.byline: By Julie Hirschfeld Davis and Maggie Haberman

articles.headline: James Staley’s Series of Unfortunate Events
articles.snippet: An inquiry, shareholder anger and an email prank cast a pall on the chief executive’s efforts to reshape Barclays.
articles.abstract: An inquiry, shareholder anger and an email prank cast a pall on the chief executive’s efforts to reshape Barclays.
articles.lead_paragraph: Days into a two-week sail across the Atlantic Ocean, Seumas Meharg reeled in a 150-pound yellowfin tuna.

articles.headline: Chastised by E.U., a Resentful Greece Embraces China’s Cash and Interests
articles.snippet: Chinese investments in Greece are beginning to pay off, not only economically, but also by providing Beijing with a seemingly reliable ally in Brussels.
articles.abstract: Chinese investments in Greece are beginning to pay off, not only economically, but also by providing Beijing with a seemingly reliable ally in Brussels.
articles.lead_paragraph: ATHENS — After years of struggling under austerity imposed by European partners and a chilly shoulder from the United States, Greece has embraced the advances of China, its most ardent and geopolitically ambitious suitor.
articles.byline: By Jason Horowitz and Liz Alderman

articles.headline: Why Trump’s Pardon of Arpaio Follows Law, Yet Challenges It
articles.snippet: Legal experts said they were troubled by President Trump’s move to excuse the lawlessness of an official who had sworn to defend the constitutional structure.
articles.abstract: Legal experts said they were troubled by President Trump’s move to excuse the lawlessness of an official who had sworn to defend the constitutional structure.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — President Trump’s decision to pardon Joe Arpaio was characteristically unconventional. It came late on a Friday night as a hurricane bore down on Texas. It concerned a crime some said was particularly ill-suited to clemency, and it was not the product of the care and deliberation that have informed pardons by other presidents.

articles.headline: Hurricane Harvey Strikes a Powerful Blow to Texas, and Lingers
articles.snippet: The first major hurricane to make landfall in the United States since 2005 caused flooding over a vast area, and officials were scrambling to assess the damage.
articles.abstract: The first major hurricane to make landfall in the United States since 2005 caused flooding over a vast area, and officials were scrambling to assess the damage.
articles.lead_paragraph: ROCKPORT, Tex. — Hurricane Harvey bombarded a stretch of the Gulf Coast in Texas on Saturday with home-ripping winds and epic rains. As emergency officials scrambled to assess the extent of the damage, hundreds of thousands of people were without power after utility poles were knocked to the ground as if they were twigs.
articles.byline: By Manny Fernandez, Alan Blinder and Simon Romero

articles.headline: Iran Out to Remake Mideast With Arab Enforcer: Hezbollah
articles.snippet: The “Party of God” has evolved from a Lebanese militant group into the spearhead of an international militia network led by Tehran.
articles.abstract: The “Party of God” has evolved from a Lebanese militant group into the spearhead of an international militia network led by Tehran.
articles.lead_paragraph: BEIRUT, Lebanon — For three decades, Hezbollah maintained a singular focus as a Lebanese military group fighting Israel. It built a network of bunkers and tunnels near Lebanon’s southern border, trained thousands of committed fighters to battle Israel’s army and built up an arsenal of rockets capable of striking far across the Jewish state.

articles.headline: Uber Chooses Expedia’s Chief as C.E.O., Ending Contentious Search
articles.snippet: Uber picked Dara Khosrowshahi as its chief executive, filling a vacancy created when the co-founder Travis Kalanick stepped down under pressure in June.
articles.abstract: Uber picked Dara Khosrowshahi as its chief executive, filling a vacancy created when the co-founder Travis Kalanick stepped down under pressure in June.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — Uber chose Dara Khosrowshahi, who leads the online travel company Expedia, to be its chief executive on Sunday, two people with knowledge of the decision said. The selection capped a contentious search process as the ride-hailing company seeks to move past a turbulent period.

articles.headline: Fatigue and Training Gaps Spell Disaster at Sea, Sailors Warn
articles.snippet: After two deadly collisions involving Navy ships, more than a dozen current and former officers raised alarms about gaps in maintenance and training, grueling duty schedules and expanded operations.
articles.abstract: After two deadly collisions involving Navy ships, more than a dozen current and former officers raised alarms about gaps in maintenance and training, grueling duty schedules and expanded operations.
articles.lead_paragraph: WASHINGTON — Two deadly collisions between high-tech destroyers and easy-to-spot, slow-moving cargo ships in a little over two months have stunned many in the Navy and sent top leaders scrambling for answers.
articles.byline: By Dave Philipps and Eric Schmitt

articles.headline: A Game You Can Control With Your Mind
articles.snippet: A number of companies are working on ways to control machines simply with a thought. But they are likely to be met with skepticism.
articles.abstract: A number of companies are working on ways to control machines simply with a thought. But they are likely to be met with skepticism.
articles.lead_paragraph: SAN FRANCISCO — When you pull the headset over your eyes and the game begins, you are transported to a tiny room with white walls. Your task is to break out of the room, but you cannot use your hands. There is no joystick or game pad. You must use your thoughts.

articles.headline: Trump Forges Ahead on Costly Nuclear Overhaul
articles.snippet: The Air Force has announced new contracts for nuclear cruise and ground-based missiles, even as some experts call the programs, which have been embraced by President Trump, unnecessary and dangerous.
articles.abstract: The Air Force has announced new contracts for nuclear cruise and ground-based missiles, even as some experts call the programs, which have been embraced by President Trump, unnecessary and dangerous.
articles.lead_paragraph: During his speech last week about Afghanistan, President Trump slipped in a line that had little to do with fighting the Taliban: “Vast amounts” are being spent on “our nuclear arsenal and missile defense,” he said, as the administration builds up the military.
articles.byline: By David E. Sanger and William J. Broad

articles.headline: So Trump Makes Spelling Errors. In the Twitter Age, Whoo Doesn’t?
articles.snippet: In tweets, the president seems to spell poorly, and he’s been flogged for it. But there’s an argument to be made that the spelling police should relax a bit.
articles.abstract: In tweets, the president seems to spell poorly, and he’s been flogged for it. But there’s an argument to be made that the spelling police should relax a bit.
articles.lead_paragraph: As protesters across the country marched in opposition to neo-Nazis this month, President Trump did something truly shocking on Twitter: He issued a level-headed statement praising the marchers.

articles.headline: Bankers and Economists Fear a Spate of Threats to Global Growth
articles.snippet: At a conference where economic policy makers usually discuss how to fuel growth, they instead worried about threats from protectionism, deregulation and the debt ceiling.
articles.abstract: At a conference where economic policy makers usually discuss how to fuel growth, they instead worried about threats from protectionism, deregulation and the debt ceiling.
articles.lead_paragraph: GRAND TETON NATIONAL PARK, Wyo. — In the decade since the financial crisis, economic policy makers, professors and protesters have gathered here every August to argue about the best ways to return to faster economic growth.

articles.headline: Samsung’s Size Could Make It Tough to Keep Its Leader in Prison
articles.snippet: The business empire’s sheer size, influence and importance to South Korea’s economy have helped its previous leaders avoid hefty prison terms.
articles.abstract: The business empire’s sheer size, influence and importance to South Korea’s economy have helped its previous leaders avoid hefty prison terms.
articles.lead_paragraph: SEOUL, South Korea — This is a partial list of the businesses of Samsung, the South Korean business empire: smartphones, microchips, insurance, gas ovens, hospitals, dishwashers, cargo ships, stocks, microwave ovens, apartment buildings, vacuum cleaners, credit cards, pharmaceuticals, air-conditioners and bidets.

articles.headline: Dramatic Rescues Unfold All Across Waterlogged Houston
articles.snippet: The authorities join private individuals in a massive effort to save those caught up in floodwaters.
articles.abstract: The authorities join private individuals in a massive effort to save those caught up in floodwaters.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — The rain had begun to fall again on Sunday afternoon when there was a roar over Interstate 610. A Texas Department of Public Safety helicopter was hovering overhead, a rescuer and a resident joined together by a harness and arms.

articles.headline: In Houston, Anxiety and Frantic Rescues as Floodwaters Rise
articles.snippet: Heavy rainfall from Tropical Storm Harvey has paralyzed the nation’s fourth-largest city. Five are dead; officials fear more trouble with more rain.
articles.abstract: Heavy rainfall from Tropical Storm Harvey has paralyzed the nation’s fourth-largest city. Five are dead; officials fear more trouble with more rain.
articles.lead_paragraph: HOUSTON — What felt like an apocalyptic onslaught of pounding rains and rapidly rising floodwaters brought the nation’s fourth-largest city to its knees on Sunday, as highways and residential streets turned to rivers, waist-high waters choked off access to homes and hospitals, and officials begged boat owners to pitch in with an enormous and frantic rescue operation.
articles.byline: By Julie Turkewitz, Manny Fernandez and Alan Blinder

articles.headline: Houston’s Hospitals Treat Storm Victims and Become Victims Themselves
articles.snippet: Houston’s world-renowned health care infrastructure found itself battered by Hurricane Harvey, testing whether officials had done enough to prepare.
articles.abstract: Houston’s world-renowned health care infrastructure found itself battered by Hurricane Harvey, testing whether officials had done enough to prepare.
articles.lead_paragraph: Water poured into hospitals. Ambulances were caught up in roiling floodwaters. Medical transport helicopters were grounded by high winds. Houston’s world-renowned health care infrastructure found itself battered by Hurricane Harvey, struggling to treat storm victims while becoming a victim itself.
articles.byline: By Sheri Fink and Alan Blinder
